svg.text: We’ve already seen, when we were styling the menu or the table,
that we can add colour to our pages in several ways. For example:
We can set the background colour of an element (we used this
to make the background of our menu purple)
We can set the colour of the text
We also can set the colours of borders and links
In fact, just about anything on the page can be coloured.
In CSS, we always use American spellings – so we
That’s just something you’ll have to get used to!
Colours can be set in two different ways:
you can give a name for a colour (such as
What we haven’t looked at is how we can choose the exact colour we want. Entering a colour name is
fine, but what if you don’t want the background of your menu to be just ‘blue’, but an exact shade of
sky blue? This is where the
come in. All the colours you see on your screen are made from
a combination of red, green and blue light at different levels of brightness. Hex codes are just a way of
setting the red, blue and green values. The first two characters after the
the next two characters represent the green part, the final two characters determine the blue part.
This theory is all very well – but how can you actually get the code of a
If you have an image-editing program such as the The GNU Image
Manipulation Program (GIMP), Adobe Photoshop or Corel Paint Shop
Pro, you can use the colour picker or colour selector tool. This allows you
to hover the cursor over a particular part of an image and get the hex
value of the colour. Or you can pop open a window and pick a colour
from a colour palette or a colour wheel.
If you don’t have an image-editing program you can use an online
Once you have the hex value of a colour, you can use it in your stylesheet. For example, if C0C0FF is the
code for the exact pastel blue colour you want to use as a background colour for your
simply add the following rule to your stylesheet:
– Have you done bases in maths at school? The reason they are called hex
codes is because the numbers are in base 16. Like this:
